doc.ContractDescription: THE PAST DECADE HAS SEEN AMAZING GROWTH IN THE FIELD OF EXOPLANETS. THANKS TO THE NASA KEPLER MISSION, WE ARE QUICKLY GAINING A CLEAR PICTURE OF THE OVERALL STATISTICAL PROPERTIES OF PLANETS ORBITING SUN-LIKE STARS. HOWEVER, WE STILL KNOW RELATIVELY LITTLE ABOUT PLANETS ORBITING LOW-MASS STARS IN THE IMMEDIATE SOLAR NEIGHBORHOOD. LOWMASS STARS ARE ATTRACTIVE TARGETS FOR PLANET SEARCHES BECAUSE IT IS FEASIBLE USING CURRENT TECHNOLOGY TO DETECT EARTH-LIKE COMPANIONS ORBITING IN THEIR HABITABLE ZONES, WHERE SURFACE TEMPERATURES COULD BE IN THE LIQUID WATER RANGE. EARTH-LIKE PLANETS ORBITING NEARBY LOW-MASS STARS WILL ALSO BE THE BEST TARGETS FOR FUTURE SPACE-BASED EFFORTS TO STUDY EXOPLANET ATMOSPHERES. WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A CONCEPT STUDY FOR A NOVEL BALLOON-BORNE DOPPLER SPECTROMETER SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO ENABLE THE FIRST CENSUS OF PLANETS ORBITING THE CLOSEST LOW-MASS STARS TO THE SUN THROUGH FUTURE LONG OR ULTRA LONG DURATION BALLOON MISSIONS. DETECTING EARTH-LIKE PLANETS ORBITING LOW-MASS STARS USING THE DOPPLER METHOD REQUIRES A SPECTROMETER THAT IS EXQUISITELY WELL CALIBRATED. SINCE LOW-MASS STARS ARE FAINT AND COOL, EMITTING MOST OF THEIR RADIATION AT INFRARED WAVELENGTHS, MEASUREMENTS OF THEIR RADIAL VELOCITIES MUST BE MADE AT WAVELENGTHS OUTSIDE THE RANGE WHERE MOST CURRENT DOPPLER SPECTROMETERS OPERATE. ANY GROUND-BASED FACILITY MUST ALSO CONTEND WITH ABSORPTION BY EARTH'S ATMOSPHERE, PARTICULARLY THAT RESULTING FROM WATER VAPOR. THIS ATMOSPHERIC ABSORPTION IMPOSES LIMITATIONS ON DOPPLER PRECISION, BUT A BALLOON FLOATS ABOVE MORE THAN 99% OF THIS WATER VAPOR. WAVELENGTH CALIBRATION IS THE KEY TO DOPPLER PRECISION. GAS IN AN ABSORPTION CELL, SUCH AS IODINE, CAN SERVE AS A CALIBRATION SOURCE BY SUPERIMPOSING SHARP ABSORPTION FEATURES ONTO A STELLAR SPECTRUM. WATER VAPOR COULD BE USED IN THIS WAY, BUT FROM THE GROUND THE NEED TO DISENTANGLE OVERLAPPING LINES FROM EARTH#S ATMOSPHERE AND THE ABSORPTION CELL MAKES THIS INFEASIBLE. AT BALLOON ALTITUDES, IT IS POSSIBLE TO USE WATER VAPOR IN A MULTI-PASS CELL FOR BROADBAND WAVELENGTH CALIBRATION AT INFRARED WAVELENGTHS. A SMALL APERTURE TELESCOPE OPERATING IN THE STRATOSPHERE CAN PERFORM NEAR THE DIFFRACTION LIMIT, ENABLING THE USE OF AN EXTREMELY COMPACT SPECTROMETER THAT IS BOTH COST-EFFECTIVE AND STABLE. WE PROPOSE CONDUCTING A CONCEPT STUDY TO CONSIDER DESIGNS FOR A BALLOON-BORNE SPECTROMETER OPTIMIZED FOR HIGH DOPPLER PRECISION. THIS CONCEPT STUDY WILL HAVE TWO MAIN PRODUCTS: 1) A DESIGN FOR A NEAR INFRARED DOPPLER SPECTROMETER FOR OPERATION FROM A BALLOON PLATFORM AND 2) A LABORATORY STUDY OF A MULTI-PASS WATER ABSORPTION CELL. STARTING FROM EXISTING INSTRUMENT DESIGNS WE WILL CARRY OUT A DETAILED STUDY TO IDENTIFY A DESIGN THAT ACHIEVES A BALANCE BETWEEN COST AND PERFORMANCE AND IS OPTIMIZED TO MAKE PRECISE RADIAL VELOCITY MEASUREMENTS OF NEARBY LOW-MASS STARS. THE MULTI-PASS WATER VAPOR CELL REPRESENTS A TOTALLY NEW METHOD FOR CALIBRATING NEAR INFRARED SPECTROMETERS, AND WE WILL MAKE LABORATORY MEASUREMENTS OF A PROTOTYPE CELL TO EVALUATE ITS SUITABILITY FOR PRECISE DOPPLER MEASUREMENTS. THE SPECTROMETER WILL BE DESIGNED FOR A FUTURE BALLOON MISSION TO CARRY OUT A COMPREHENSIVE CENSUS OF PLANETS ORBITING A VOLUME-LIMITED SAMPLE OF LOW-MASS STARS IN THE SOLAR NEIGHBORHOOD. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL BE IN DIRECT SUPPORT OF THE NASA KEY STRATEGIC SCIENTIFIC GOALS TO "ASCERTAIN THE CONTENT, ORIGIN, AND EVOLUTION OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM AND THE POTENTIAL FOR LIFE ELSEWHERE" AND "SEARCH FOR EARTH-LIKE PLANET". FURTHER, THIS STUDY WILL EXPLORE A NEW TECHNOLOGY FOR MAKING DOPPLER MEASUREMENTS AT INFRARED WAVELENGTHS USING A WATER VAPOR CELL. SUPPORT FOR THIS PROJECT THROUGH THE ROMAN TECHNOLOGY FELLOWSHIP WILL ALSO ENABLE THE PI TO ACQUIRE CRITICAL SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE THAT WILL PREPARE HIM TO PLAY A LEADING ROLE IN FUTURE INSTRUMENTATION EFFORTS AND NASA MISSIONS.
